prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors articulated by the Panel in selecting transferee district—Size of actions

para.paratext: The Panel has also considered the size of the actions in determining where they should be transferred.[1] This factor is not frequently articulated in the Panel's decisions and it is probably not a significant factor in most cases. It may come into play, however, if the venue of the pending actions is not determinative. It essentially allows the “weighting” of the venue of the pending actions. In one case the Panel considered transfer of seven active actions essentially evenly distributed among three districts. The Panel transferred the cases to the Northern District of Illinois because one of the cases venued there involved perhaps twice as much money as the aggregate of the cases pending elsewhere.[2] In another case involving multiple class actions, the Panel simply noted that the selected transferee district was the district where the first-filed and largest action was filed.[3]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Admission Tickets, 302 F. Supp. 1339, 1341 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

See, e.g., In re Novartis Wage and Hour Litigation, 460 F. Supp. 2d 1382 (J.P.M.L. 2006); In re Admission Tickets, 302 F. Supp. 1339, 1341 (J.P.M.L. 1969). Accord In re Revenue Properties Co., 309 F. Supp. 1002, 1004 (J.P.M.L. 1970).

In re Elevator and Escalator Antitrust Litigation, 350 F. Supp. 2d 1351 (J.P.M.L. 2004). See also In re Wayne Farms LLC Fair Labor Standards Act Litigation, 528 F. Supp. 2d 1355 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (Panel notes large number of claimants in actions).
